title: So can I get the thought process behind Kalista? Seriously?
body:
Okay so you make a champion that can dash on any auto attack. Reasonably the only champions that this will matter against is melee. Why? Because range will be... still at range, and longer ranged opponents will be... still in range. The only people this impacts negatively is melee. 

So you start with a champion that just has a basis on an anti-melee mechanic and you then proceed to make the rest of her kit...

and you give her %health damage? But not %Health damage in physical so you could reasonably defend against her, you give her %health damage in magic... 20% damage. As if being able to kite out every melee champion wasn't enough you turn around and say "hey you know that OTHER mechanic that totally screws over melee? Lets give her that one too!"

I'm just struggling here. Are you guys even trying to keep things fair anymore? Have you just given up? Is the thought process now "well range already have so much of an advantage on melee that we can't make it any worse, right?" 

At some point did Kalista not have %health damage and you guys went "hey man that guy who built all tank items doesn't take tons of damage from our passive effect on half of one ability, we should totally make it %health damage so you can totally notice that free damage chunking away a tank's HP!" 

Also, did NOBODY at Riot HQ notice the irony of doing the Sion revamp then immediately turning around and releasing Kalista? Like nobody was going to think "so melee champions are going to be big and bulky now... and ranged champions will just effortlessly avoid everything they do anyway, huh?" It's like Olaf didn't teach Riot anything, they didn't realize that access to easy spammable escape moves renders an entire archtype completely useless, and that once spammy escape move champions get popular that nobody will touch the non-gap closing melee champions with a ten foot pole. "OH BUT MUNDO!" yeah and Mundo lost every single game except one at worlds, and then people stopped playing him once they realized he wasn't good at winning games but rather only looking cool. 

Or maybe somebody was just jealous that Lucian was ruining the meta all by himself and that he needed more company.

*And she also needs a good health pool, good armor pool, good base damage, normal attack range, no mana issues, and all the free survivability you can eat. Counterplay? Weaknesses? Nah those are for melee champions. Lets revamp another melee champion in to a non-meta piece of shit and think about how much better we can make ADCs!*

Either you didn't really look into how Kalista works, or you're missing something here. 

Firstly, you have to note that every other ranged champion in the game has a weaker version of her passive. It's called micro, or stutter-stepping or orbwalking (although technically orbwalking is wrong.) Because Kalista can't cancel her autoattacks, she doesn't get nearly as much free mobility as it would seem if you leave this point out. Also, if you leave this point out you leave our her biggest weakness, when she attacks she commits. That means Leona can land a free e, Ezreal can land a free Q, etc. This is EXTREMELY prevalent in lane phase, where she has low attackspeed and thus can't dash very quickly.

The mechanic isn't specifically anti-melee, (if anything, you could say it's anti-slows, because it's not reduced by slowing, which normal micro is.) because every ranged champ can do this and get similar returns on it. The extra range on backwards jump is good when people are chasing you, regardless of who they are.

At the fifth paragraph is where you really start to go off the rails, though. You emphasize how her % health damage is magic, and how that screws over tanks, yet fail to mention how she has no actual steriod, putting her likely only slightly ahead of Caitlyn in terms of mid-late game dps. 

If you want to specifically talk about how certain melee champs are pretty bad (which is what it seems like your last 3 paragraphs are about) then a general topic isn't the place to do it. In no way are all melee characters bad in LoL. Easy examples are Lee, Rammus, and Zed.

Yes, this is the thing people seem to forget.  Kalista seems to be billed as a light damage ranged attacker who has tons of utility.  Kalista is going to be a powerful champion for the **high elo vs high elo games**, and absolutely suck in all other regards, like other utility Marksmen.  Ashe, Varus, etc?  Remember them?  Piss poor win rates and popularity in low elo, yet dominates in high elo.

The place I see Kalista being used is in a more non-ADC based team, where the **real** carry is an AD mid, jungle, or top.  Kalista is a ranged "Support" Marksman that can apply some damage and plenty of utility from range.  People are going to dive her and kill her and dominate her.  But lose the game.  The guy they needed to shut and put down was somewhere else.

You see this in many games.  A team focuses down the Marksman, yet lets Master Yi take a pentakill and six items.  They try a 5v4 that wins, but lose an inhibitor tower and the inhibitor too at the same time as the teamfight.

Yo, I am 'high elo' (Diamond 3), and Ashe and Varus don't see play in Solo Queue. Ashe sees some play in Ranked 5's, but she is still very unpopular. Varus sees none. 

Kalista is an ADC, not a ranged Support. She provides high dps (relative to other classes) in the lategame, and is ranged. That's basically all Ranged ADCs need to do.

I don't think you fully understand me.  I'm not saying Kalista *can't* be used as a full blown carry.  I'm saying she has the same issue as other, rather low damage, utility carries.  Kalista will never reach hypercarry status, though she reach could skirmisher status.  I said support as in fire support.  You people seem to see one definition only when reading words with multiple definitions.  Kalista isn't a machine gun.  Kalista is your designated rifleman, providing consistent, but not mind blowing DPS down range.

> The DM's role is to supply rapid accurate fire on enemy targets at ranges up to 550 yards (500 m) with a rifle capable of semi-automatic fire called a designated marksman rifle equipped with a telescopic sight. Like snipers, DMs are trained in quick and precise shooting, but unlike the more specialized "true" sniper, they are also attached to an infantry fireteam and intended to lay down accurate rapid fire at valuable targets as needed, thus extending the reach of the Fireteam.
